ygData.msgSnippet: ... Hi Chad, I would keep the monochromatic input and attach 3 new color signals. That way previously evolved genomes can be used (with the new inputs added)

Chad Bohannan wrote:

> how do you differentiate between similar types of information with NEAT?
> I understand that the input should represent intensity, but what if I 
> want to add more information? For instance: color.
> The only approach I see is to just tack on inputs that begin the same 
> as any other input. For a three color system, the eye just got three 
> times many more dimensions complicated. Is there any way to scale from 
> a monochromatic solution to a color solution, without forcing a new 
> search?


Hi Chad, I would keep the monochromatic input and attach 3 new color 
signals. That way previously evolved genomes can be used (with the new 
inputs added) in the start population and mainatian their existing 
functionality. You also might want to look at different color 
representation systems, Red/Green/Blue is the system used in biological 
eyes (or most of them AFAIK) but there are other schemes such as 
Hue/Saturation//Brightness. So for instance in *that* scheme the 
monochromatic input is effectively a brightness input so you only need 
two more inputs.

Colin.
